description: This talk explores where the tech frontier (crypto, prog-crypto, network states) meets the philosophical frontier (Plurality, Cypherpunk, d/acc, Lunarpunk, BAM). We map uncommon ground and show how "intolerant minorities" can drive decentralized ch

transcript.aggregated_text: What sense making at the at the front here? All good. Yeah. Polarity and procrypto. Right. So, a few things I'm not going to talk to you about. I'm not going to talk to you about uh Vaku, which is a peer-to-peer communication protocol with a focus on privacy and sensor persistence. I'm not going to talk to you about uh MOPro, which is a tool that I worked on for client side CK proving. I'm not going to talk to you about the book I'm writing on CK seek intro. Instead, what I want to do is sort of take a step back. Uh and basically, I've been going to these like conferences and pop-up cities and hackathons and so on for many years now. And what I've noticed is that there like a lot of philosophies that people are inventing or or keep coming back to. So whether it's like cipher punk, solar punk, lunar punk, diaak, plurality, bronze age mindset and so on. And I think what you what I've noticed is that a lot of these philosophies they often come in conjunction with some technology. One of the things I ask is like are they in opposition? Are they in conflict and like where do they overlap? Uh there's some obvious conflicts. So kind of bronze mindset versus solar punk. I think the former is more on sort of the some kind of heroic elitism versus solar punk which is more of a communal optimism and also differences in terms of if it's more like romantic cyber punk vision versus some kind of tempered transparency and working with existing institutions. Uh I think a big difference is also in terms of how these philosophies think about institutions. Are they trying to reform existing institutions or rejecting them completely? But over overall I would say there's more overlap than this conflict. Uh in general there's like a large skepticism for central of central authorities and most of them also are pursuing new forms of coordination and in general I would sum it up as kind of new world versus old world. uh when it comes to trust and some shared problems, there's some shared trust problems. So like how do you trust at scale and how do you deal with things like authenticity, privacy and accountability without having some kind of centralized top down uh control and a big intersection here is kind of trying to exit these broken systems or building better ones. Uh and here I want to talk a little bit about tribalism. Uh going back to plurality. So they have this vision of like data democracy, right? So starting off with some notion or multiple notions of identity and then association on top of that and then commerce contracts and then finally access. And I also want to point out that this idea of democracy, it doesn't just apply to sort of nation states. It's kind of a general um way of thinking about how do we govern various platforms and so on. So for example, how how does governance for Twitter work? So first up identity uh so the challenge here is enimity versus central control. So on the left here you have so no one knows your dog on internet and on the right you have this kind of top down civilian state and both are kind of failure modes in a sense uh because you have things like civil resistance and and so on and reputation you want to have. So you need one or multiple notions of some kind of secure identity in order to have some kind of digital democracy or governance. One example of this is quite interesting is Rharmo. So Rammo is a CK solution and is used in Ukraine, Russia and Georgia. And if you're a fan of geopolitics, you know that these uh jurisdictions are quite different. So in the case of Ukraine, it's more sort of aligned. In the case of Russia, it's uh something that is uh has to be done permissionlessly. So basically what it what it does is that you have maybe a Russian passport and then you can they have this shadow election and they're doing it permissionlessly and that's something you can do with this technology. And in case of Georgia they also did this experiment with liquid democracy so you could sort of have a more involved uh people in terms of the decision-m process and so on. So that's the kind of private set intersection part. Uh and this is also done technologically uh through 2PC specifically. So there's no you're not revealing it to a central server or anything like that. Um and with this they have this kind of idea of digital pherommones where basically you give up some some kind of pherommones and then if other people have the receptors uh then you can sort of match. And I think this is very interesting because an example of a new type of affordance that you don't see from traditional social networks and you can sort of create these new ways of of interacting with this technology. When it comes to commerce uh at a high level you can look at a bit like cash versus CBDC versus crypto. And cash is is is kind of dumb but it works really well. So basically what you can do is you can as a user you can get privacy and disassociate your funds from a big hack.
